## Initiative
:::{.nonincremental style="color: black; background-image: url('./assets/slide_template/gf_slide.png'); font-size: 28px; padding-bottom: 20px;"}

::: {.column width="50%"}
- **Brief Description:**
  Build and maintain a curated library of high-quality samples created by IDM researchers and software engineers demonstrating data access and data analysis techniques worth sharing with colleagues.

- **Motivation and Framing:**
  Uploading notebook samples to GitHub is straightforward, but how do we ensure their content truly benefits the Global Public Good? Researchers seek to share their algorithms, models, and visualizations in a reproducible, interactive format, promoting open collaboration, peer review, and knowledge exchange.

## Quarto: A versatile publishing tool

:::{.standard-slide}

- Doesn’t have a dependency or requirement for R.

- Multilingual, support for R, Python, Javascript, and Julia…

- Best suited for collaborating on scientific and technical documents

- Learn More [here](https://quarto.org/docs/faq/rmarkdown.html)

![](./assets/slide_intro/slide_7.png){width=100% height=100% align=center}

:::
---

## Racap of Quarto Features
:::{.standard-slide style="font-size: 28px;"}


| **Quarto** | **RMardown** |
|-------------|-------------|
| Supports Python, R, Julia, and  [Observable](https://observablehq.com/). | Primarily uses R for dynamic content.|
| Offers a wider range of publishing options, including articles, presentations, dashboards, websites, blogs, and books in HTML, PDF, MS Word, ePub, and more.  | Limited publishing format: HTML, PDF, and MS Word. |
| Support a variety of authoring tools like VS Code, RStudio, Jupyter Lab, any text editor, and a visual markdown editor. | Typically uses RStudio as its primary authoring environment.  |
| Facilitates advanced interactivity with Jupyter Widgets, htmlwidgets for R, Observable JS, and Shiny. Quarto extensions simplifes the usage.  | Offers interactivity but require additional complicated setup. |


:::
---

## YAML Header & Document Structure

:::{.standard-slide height=100%}


- **YAML Header**: Defines metadata (title, author, date, output format, etc.).

- **Document Structure**:
  - Text: For narratives and explanations.
  - Code Chunks: Embedded Python / R code for analysis and visualizations.
  - Execution options: Supports multiple outputs with easy configuration for code execution.
  - Tables, Figures, and Equations: Compatible with markdown syntax.
  - Callouts: For highlighting important points.

:::

## Quarto Markdown (.qmd) Examples

:::{.standard-slide style="font-size: 32px;"}

````markdown
---
title: "Quarto Document Example with Labeled Code"
author: "John Smith"
date: "2025-02-15"
format: html
---
# Introduction
This document demonstrates Quarto’s R code chunk.

## Basic Calculation Example
This section calculates the mean of a vector.
The code chunk below is labeled as `calculate_mean` for easier reference.

` ` `{r calculate_mean}
#| echo: true
#| eval: false
# This chunk calculates the mean of a vector of numbers
numbers <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
mean_value <- mean(numbers)
mean_value
` ` `
````
:::

---
## Execution Options

:::{.standard-slide style="font-size: 32px;"}

- `warning=FALSE`: Suppresses warnings.
- `include=FALSE`: Hides code and output but runs the code.
- `echo=FALSE`: Hides code but shows output, useful for report-style documents.
- `eval=FALSE`:Do not run the code. (some code may need special setup or prompts for credentials)

```markdown
` ` `{r warning=FALSE}

OR

` ` `{r}
#| warning: false

` ` `
````
- Check [here](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/execution-options.html) for more options.
:::

## Quarto for Python
:::{.standard-slide}
- **Jupyter Engine Integration**: Quarto natively supports Jupyter notebooks (.ipynb) as well as Quarto markdown documents (.qmd) by leveraging the Jupyter engine for execution.
- **Execution control**: When rendering an .ipynb Quarto will not execute the cells within the notebook by default (use <i>quarto render notebook.ipynb --execute</i>)
- For more information, visit [Quarto for Python](https://quarto.org/docs/computations/python.html)
- [VS code extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=quarto.quarto) is available.
:::


## Quarto Extensions
:::{.standard-slide}
- Includes new formats (e.g. Journal articles), shortcodes (Reusable custom components), and templates.
- Use <b>quarto add quarto-ext/{ext-name}</b> to install extensions distributed from the [quarto-ext](https://github.com/quarto-ext/) GitHub
- Manage with <b>quarto list extensions</b> | <b>quarto remove quarto-ext/{ext-name} | quarto update quarto-ext/{ext-name} </b>
- Rather than installing into a global library, Quarto extensions are stored locally, directly alongside your project / files.
- For more information, visit [Quarto Extensions](https://quarto.org/docs/extensions/).
:::
